title: When should one buy armor/magic resist?
body: In what situation should one buy armor/magic resist, and when exactly in that game should you get it? Thanks!

replies.body:
TL DR:

Remember the following rule:

    At 50 Armor I should have 1100 HP
    At 100 Armor I should have 1500 HP
    At 150 Armor I should have 1900 HP

http://i.imgur.com/Wyg0ODz.png

Please have a look to the album:

http://imgur.com/a/3qUe8

I will only present the conclusions here, if you are interested by the calculations of the equilibrium curve, read this document: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1DAuUphj2IAt3QDk_WkfoVqydZ_e7cRCzpFewz9aubU8/edit?usp=sharing

**General conclusions:**

    When you are under the curve, buy health, when you are above the curve, buy armor or magic resist:

http://i.imgur.com/Wyg0ODz.png

    The previous conclusion DOES NOT depend on the AD / AP of your opponent. Even if this veigar has 1500 AP, if you have 70 MR and 1000 health you should buy health and not magic resist.

    Before the lvl 10 it is more gold efficient to buy health, after the level 10 it is more gold efficient to buy armor or magic resist:

http://i.imgur.com/W2SLkzF.png

    Last Whisper and Void Staff move the equilibrium curve. But, against a Void Staff, buying Magic Resist on range champions is still a better option than buying health:

http://i.imgur.com/RdewlmT.png

    Rammus gains a huge amount of Armor and MR from his W. Buying health on Rammus is way more efficient early game.

http://i.imgur.com/irAKDrj.png

    Cho'Gath (and Renekton in a different way) gains a lot of health from his R. At 6 stacks Cho is widely above the curve. Cho'Gath should NOT buy health. No Rod of Ages. No.

http://i.imgur.com/5ZFOLCW.png

    Malphite W bring him 40% bonus armor, and at lvl 18 he is above the curve. So late game armor is very gold efficient on him. But, early game, malphite should buy health before armor (before lvl 12):

http://i.imgur.com/HnRIF0d.png


If you disagree with one of my conclusions, or if you think I made a mistake somewhere, please tell me!

As many of you will point out: This is pure math outside of any real context. In game you won't be able to buy 66 HP for 110 gold. Every item comes with a mix of stat and a passive that must be considered.

About the statement: "health is always more gold efficient early". This does not mean: " build giant belt on Ahri 1st item". Health pots are an excellent way to buy health early for champs that won't need that stat late. Don't forget that after lvl10 armor and mr are better than health. (Rammus still should buy health though)

The results hereby presented are a simplification of a very complex and situational problem. The calculations are based on the linearization of a non-linear problem between Physical and Magic dmg taken independently. In case the enemy team is hybrid, health becomes up to twice as important since it amplifies both Armor and Magic Resistance.

> If you disagree with one of my conclusions, or if you think I made a mistake somewhere, please tell me!

That's kind of a very broad question, and it won't get you the answer you're looking for. What specific role are we referring to?

It depends on who you're playing and what/how they best scale. It also depends on the enemy composition, who's the biggest threat and so on.

In general, if you're playing a tank or bruiser, you'll want at least one armor, Mr, and a health item. The order that you build them in is 100% situational. Squisher champions aren't as dependent on defensive itemization to do their jobs, so for them you pick 1 or 2 items that help them stay alive and keep doing damage.

Tl;dr for tanky champions you want an even Balance of defenses before late game hits. For squishes you'll want at least one defensive item, but don't prioritize it unless you're behind AND it at least provides some dps.

I can't handle narrow minded people who think that there is always a yes/no question or an exact time or place to build x y or z. There are so many factors in a game that influence what you should be building.
Maybe you should be a little nicer with a **level 18** guy that is asking for advice while he's learning the game, don't you think?

It's situational, but if you're building tank I'd say start cloth armor, then build your health first, then finish the item (probably Randuins)
If you're fighting ap go for spirit visage first. 
If you're support then build your gold income item first, which would probably be face of mountain for tanks supp. 
If you're ad or ap carry, it's probably better to not buy health or armor and just get more damage.
The way it works is it makes your health more x more effective, where x is your armor/Magic resist.  So 100 armor and 1000 health would mean it would take 2000 Ad damage to kill you. So building 50 armor and getting 1500 health would give you 2250 effective health (better).
Always
generally you get a health item first, then a resistance + health item. assuming you are building moderately tanky.
Popularly, if you are behind build damage output while if you're ahead build armor/MR.  Unless you're the tank, then build straight outta the gate health and armor/MR.

There are a fair few variables at play in that decision. It's easier to see a pro game and say why they picked it in that particular game than it is to outline a kind of large decision tree. It depends on who you are playing, what you intended to do in the game (team fight, split push) and who you are against, both in lane and holistically. It also depends somewhat on if you are ahead or behind.
Thank you for an actual answer
